A Glimpse On Cantor Function

Jun 27, 2021

On Cantor’s Function Presentation Competition, June 2021 Ramakrishna Mission Vidyamandira

Introduction

Cantor set (or, Cantor ternary set) is an intriguing and unusual subset of \(\mathbb{R}\), which is constructed by successively removing "middle thirds" from the interval \([0,1]\). We denote the Cantor set by : \(\Delta\). Set theory tells us that \(\Delta\) is uncountable. More precisely, The cardinality of Cantor’s set is the continuum. That is, Cantor’s set has the same cardinality as the interval \([0, 1]\) and that of the whole \(\mathbb{R}\). Measure theory tells us that \(\Delta\) is "small", i.e., it has measure \(0\). Topology tells us that \(\Delta\) is a perfect set and is totally disconnected. And also, Geometry tells us that \(\Delta\) is a Fractal (self-similar).

From the construction of \(\Delta\), we also have \(x \in \Delta\), if and only if \(x\) can be written as \(\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{a_n}{3^n}\), where each \(a_n \in \{0,2\}\). With all these properties in mind, we define a correspondence between \(\Delta\) and \([0,1]\) in the following section.

The Cantor Function

We define the Cantor function \(f: \Delta \to [0,1]\) by \[f\left(\sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{2b_n}{3^n}\right)= \sum\limits_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{b_n}{2^n} \qquad (b_n = 0, 1).\]i.e. \[f(0.a_1a_2a_3\ldots (\text{base } 3))=0.\frac{a_1}{2}\frac{a_2}{2}\frac{a_3}{2}\cdots (\text{base 2}) \qquad (a_n = 0, 2).\]

From the definition of the Cantor function, we can see that \(f\) is increasing. i.e., if \(x,y \in \Delta\) with \(x<y\), then \(f(x)\leq f(y)\). Now, if \(x \in \Delta\) has two ternary expansions, i.e., \(x=0.a_1a_2\ldots a_n1= 0.a_1a_2\ldots a_n0222\ldots\), then \[\begin{aligned} f(x)&=f(0.a_1a_2\ldots a_n1 (\text{base } 3)) \\ &= f(0.a_1a_2\ldots a_n0222\ldots(\text{base } 3)) \\ &= 0.b_1b_2\ldots b_n0111\ldots (\text{base } 2) \qquad(b_n = 0, 1) \\ &= 0.b_1b_2\ldots b_n1 (\text{base } 2) \\ &= f(0.a_1a_2\ldots a_n2 (\text{base } 3)) \end{aligned}\] Now, if \(x, y \in \Delta\) are consecutive endpoints of the form \(x=0.a_1a_2\ldots a_n1\) and \(y=0.a_1a_2\ldots a_n2\) in base \(3\), then from the previous result, we have \(f(x)=f(y)\). Hence we have the following result:

Let \(f:\Delta \to [0,1]\) be the Cantor function (defined above) and let \(x,y \in \Delta\) with \(x<y\). Then \(f(x) \leq f(y)\). Equality holds if and only if \(x\) and \(y\) are consecutive endpoints.

Now, as the Cantor function is surjective, we have \(|\Delta| \geq |[0,1]|\), and by construction of Cantor set, \(|\Delta| \leq |[0,1]|\). Hence, from Schoeder-Bernstein theorem, \(|\Delta|=|[0,1]|\). So, \(\Delta\) is uncountable and has cardinality equal to that of continuum.

With the above properties of the cantor function defined on \(\Delta\), we extend this function on the interval \([0,1]\) in the following section.

Extended Cantor Function

With the observation in Proposition 0.1, we take \(f\) to be an appropriate constant on each of the open intervals that make up \([0,1]\backslash \Delta\). For example, \(f(x)=f(1/3)=1/2\) for each \(x\) in the interval \((1/3,2/3)\), and \(f(x)=f(1/9)=1/4\) for each \(x \in (1/9,2/9)\).

We define \[f(x)= \sup\{f(y):y\in \Delta, y \leq x\} \qquad \forall~ x \in [0,1]\backslash \Delta\]

Now, since the Cantor function is increasing and the extended function is constant on every open interval, \(f\) is increasing on \([0,1]\). Also from the definition of Cantor function, we have \(f\) is a surjection, which is easy to verify. Now we prove the continuity of \(f\) in \([0,1]\). To prove the desired result we use the following theorem.

If \(f:(a,b) \to \mathbb{R}\) is monotone, then \(f\) has atmost countably many points of discontinuity in \((a,b)\) and all of which are jump discontinuities.

If \(f: [a,b] \to [c,d]\) is both monotone and onto, then \(f\) is continuous.

Corollary :The Cantor function \(f:[0,1]\to [0,1]\) is continuous.

Hence, we have the required result that, the function \(f\) is increasing and continuous. Again \(f'=0\) at almost every point in \([0,1]\), i.e. \(f'=0\) on \([0,1]\backslash \Delta\), a set of measure \(1\). So, \(f\) is also called singular function.

We have therefore shown that \(f\) is continuous, monotonic, non-constant, and singular. We now investigate the differentiability of \(f\) at the points of \(\Delta\).

At a left hand endpoint of a complementary interval, the right-hand derivative exists and is equal to \(0\). And similarly, a left-hand derivative at a right hand end point of is equal to \(0\).

Now, let \(x=0.a_1a_2\ldots a_n200\ldots\) (base \(3\)), be a right hand end point. Let, \(m>n\) and \(h \in (3^{-m-1},3^{-m})\), hence, \[\frac{3^{m}}{2^{m+1}} \leq \frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h} \leq \frac{3^{m+1}}{2^m}\]Now, \(h\to 0 \implies m \to \infty\), therefore, \[\lim\limits_{m \to \infty}\frac{3^m}{2^{m+1}} \leq \lim\limits_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x+h)-f(x)}{h} \leq \lim\limits_{m \to \infty} \frac{3^{m+1}}{2^m}\] Hence, at a right hand end point and a left hand end point \(x\), we have right hand derivative \(f'_+(x)=+\infty\) and left hand derivative \(f'_-(x)=0\).

Cantor Type Functions

One of the major breakthroughs in the history of mathematics, i.e., one of the first set-theoretical result of Cantor was his discovery of the existence of a bijection between \(\mathbb{R}\) and \(\mathbb{R}^2\). A previously known result was a bijection between \(\mathbb{N}\) and \(\mathbb{N} \times \mathbb{N}\).

The standard partition \((\{0, 2, 4, \ldots\}, \{1, 3, 5, \ldots\})\) of \(\mathbb{N}\) into two infinite sets shows the existence of a bijection between \(\mathbb{N}\) and \((\mathbb{N} \times \{0\}) \cup (\mathbb{N} \times \{1\})\). By starting with the latter bijection, it is not hard to establish a one-to-one correspondence between \(\mathbb{R}\) and \(\mathbb{R}^2\) (respectively, between the unit segment \([0, 1]\) and the unit square \([0,1]^2\)).

Keeping these in mind we define the following.

Definition :A map \(f:\mathbb{R}\to \mathbb{R}^2\) (respectively from \([0,1]\) into \([0,1]^2\)) is a Cantor type function if \(f\) is a bijection.

With the previous discussion, it is now clear that Cantor type function exists. Now we have the following theorems.

Theorem : If \(f\) is a cantor type function, then it is not continuous.

Proof

If possible, let \(f\) is continuous. Then we wrte, \[\mathbb{R}^2 = \bigcup_{n \in \mathbb{N}} f([-n,n])\]where \(f([-n,n])\) is compact (closed) in \(\mathbb{R}^2\), \(\forall~ n \in \mathbb{N}\). Now, from Baire Category Theorem, at least one of these sets have non-empty interior. Let \(k \in \mathbb{N}\) be such that \((f([-k,k]))^{\circ} \neq \phi.\) So, we have the bijective continuous mapping \[f|_{[-k,k]}:[-k,k]\to f([-k,k])\]which is a homeomorphism between \([-k,k]\) to \(f([-k,k])\). So, the function \(f^{-1}\) defined by \[f^{-1}|_{f([-k,k])}:f([-k,k])\to [-k,k]\]is also a homeomorphism. Now, let \(L \subset f([-k,k])\) such that \(L\) is isometric to \[\{(x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^2:x^2+y^2=r, r>0\}\](The existence of \(L\) is guaranteed from the result that \(f([-k,k])\) has non-empty interior in \(\mathbb{R}^2\).) Therefore, \[f^{-1}|_L: L \to [-k,k]\]is injective and continuous. This is a contradiction, since there is no injective continuous function acting from a circle into the real line. Hence the theorem.

Theorem : Let \(f:\mathbb{R}^2\to \mathbb{R}\) be continuous with respect to each variables \(x,y\in\mathbb{R}\), then \(f\) is not an injection.

Proof

Let, if possible \(f\) is injective. Define, \(\phi(x)=f(x,0), \forall~ x\in\mathbb{R}\). Then \(\phi:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}\) is continuous. Put \(\phi(0)=a, \phi(1)=b\). Since \(f\) is injective, we have \(a \neq b\). Without loss of generality, assume \(a<b\). Since \(\phi\) is continuous on \([0,1]\), we have \([\phi(0),\phi(1)]=[a,b].\) In particular, \(\exists~x_0\in(0,1)\) such that \[\phi(x_0)=\frac{a+b}{2}.\]Now, define \(\psi(y)=f(x_0,y), \forall~y\in\mathbb{R}.\) Then \(\psi\) is continuous and \[\psi(0)=f(x_0,0)=\phi(x_0)=\frac{a+b}{2}\]Therefore, we have \(a<\psi(0)<b.\) Since, \(\psi\) is continuous, there exists a neighborhood \(N(0)\) of \(0\) such that \[a<\psi(y)=f(x_0,y)<b \quad \forall~y\in N(0).\]Hence we have \(\{f(x_0,y):y\in N'(0)\}\subset (a,b) \subset \{f(x,0):0 \leq x < 1\}\). Therefore, \(\exists~ y_0\neq 0\) and \(x_1 \in \mathbb{R}\) such that \(f(x_0,y_0)=f(x_1,0)\). Which contradicts the injectivity of \(f\).

So, our assumption that \(f\) is continuous is false. Hence the theorem.

Conclusion

  • Firstly, we conclude that the Cantor Function is a increasing function in \([0,1]\), and again \(f'(x)=0\) at almost every point in its domain. Which is counter-intuitive. And we call such functions : Singular Function.

  • From the second observation, it is reasonable to ask whether there exist continuous surjections from \(\mathbb{R}\) onto \(\mathbb{R}^2\) or from \([0,1]\) onto \([0,1]^2\). It turns out that such surjections do exist. The example of a continuous surjective function acting from \([0,1]\) onto \([0,1]^2\) was first constructed Peano. These kind of functions are known as Peano type function.

  • In order to demonstrate the existence of Peano type functions, we again have to use the classical Cantor construction of his famous discontinuum, \(\Delta\).

  • Let \(E\) be an arbitrary nonempty compact metric space. Then there exists a continuous surjection acting from \(\Delta\) onto \(E.\)

References

  1. Real Analysis, N.L. Carothers, First Edition, Reprint 2019, Page : 25-31

  2. Introduction to Topology and Modern Analysis, G.F. Simmons, Fourth Reprint 2005, Page : 67-69

  3. A primer of real functions, Ralph P. Boas, Fourth Edition 1996, Page : 158-163
